description: From Middle English frele, fraill, from Old French fraile, from Latin fragilis. Cognate to fraction, fracture, and doublet of fragile.

entries.meaning: Easily broken physically; not firm or durable; liable to fail and perish.
examples: Its nest is composed of the frailest materials, and is light and small in proportion to the size of the bird
O as the soft and frail lights break upon your eyelids

entries.meaning: (medicine) In an infirm state leading one to be easily subject to disease or other health problems, especially regarding the elderly.
Liable to fall from virtue or be led into sin; not strong against temptation; weak in resolution; unchaste.

examples: She was the roughest, toughest frail, but Minnie had a heart as big as a whale.

verbs.description: frail (third-person singular simple present frails, present participle frailing, simple past and past participle frailed)

entries.meaning: To play a stringed instrument, usually a banjo, by picking with the back of a fingernail.

description: From Middle English frayel, from Old French frael, fraiel, of unknown origin; possibly a dissimilatory variant of flael, flaiel (“flail”).

entries.meaning: A basket made of rushes, used chiefly to hold figs and raisins.
The quantity of fruit or other items contained in a frail.

examples: The scythe, the sickle and the flail (or "frail", is it is invariably called) - these should surely be incorporated in the county arms, for on their use much of the prosperity of Essex has always rested until now.
